title: Air Canada's record revenue fails to boost profit as 737 Max grounding weighs
text:
Record third-quarter revenue helped lift Air Canada’s earnings though its profit fell compared to a year ago as it coped with the grounding of three dozen Boeing 737 Max aircraft.

Profit for the three months to Sept. 30 slipped to $636 million or $2.35 per diluted share compared to third quarter 2018 profit of $702 million or $2.55 per diluted share, the Montreal-based airline reported.

Passenger revenue expanded by 2.9 per cent to $5.16 billion in the three months compared with the same period a year earlier despite a 2.1 per cent decline in capacity, the airline said. Total revenue for the quarter was $5.55 billion, it said.

Analysts were expecting revenue of $5.62 billion, according to Bloomberg. The airline had to remove 36 Boeing 737 Max aircraft from service during its peak summer months of operation after the model suffered two fatal crashes within five months.

“The grounding is preventing us from realizing our full potential,” Calin Rovinescu, president and CEO of Air Canada, said in a statement Tuesday.

Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization and impairment rose $121 million or 9 per cent from the year earlier period to $1.472 billion as operating income rose to $956 million from $923 million in the third quarter of 2018, Air Canada said.

Rovinescu said the record revenue and higher earnings “are even more meaningful given that we achieved them despite the serious disruption to our operations and to our cost structure created by the Boeing 737 MAX grounding.”

Air Canada said it expects to return its Boeing 737 Max planes to service by Feb. 14. Meantime, it has leased two Airbus A330 planes to ensure sufficient capacity over the winter, Rovincescu said.

The company kept its full-year guidance issued in February of an earnings margin of 19 per cent, return on invested capital of 15.5 per cent to 16 per cent and its free cash flow estimate of $1.3 billion to $1.5 billion.

“I nonetheless remain confident that if regulators unground the aircraft near-term, our on-going transformation will quickly regain its previous trajectory,” Rovinescu said. “For this reason, we have chosen at this time not to adjust our long-term financial targets.”
description: The grounding of 36 aircraft ‘is preventing us from realizing our full potential’ — CEO
